deck.name: Rifle & Carbine Marksmanship
deck.description: TC 3-22.9 - M4/M16 specifications, zeroing, fundamentals, engagement techniques, and maintenance

cards.front: What is the maximum effective range of the M4 carbine (point target)?
cards.back:
500 meters.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: What is the maximum effective range of the M4 carbine (area target)?
cards.back:
600 meters.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: What is the maximum effective range of the M16A2/A3/A4 (point target)?
cards.back:
550 meters.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: What is the maximum effective range of the M16A2/A3/A4 (area target)?
cards.back:
800 meters.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: What caliber ammunition does the M4/M16 fire?
cards.back:
5.56mm NATO (.223 caliber).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, para 1-2)

cards.front: What is the cyclic rate of fire for the M4/M16?
cards.back:
700-970 rounds per minute.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: What is the sustained rate of fire for the M4/M16?
cards.back:
12-15 rounds per minute.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: What is the rapid rate of fire for the M4/M16?
cards.back:
45 rounds per minute.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: How many rounds does a standard M4/M16 magazine hold?
cards.back:
30 rounds.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, para 1-3)

cards.front: What is the muzzle velocity of the M4 carbine?
cards.back:
Approximately 2,970 feet per second (905 m/s).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: What is the muzzle velocity of the M16A2/A4?
cards.back:
Approximately 3,100 feet per second (940 m/s).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: What is the barrel length of the M4 carbine?
cards.back:
14.5 inches.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: What is the barrel length of the M16A2/A3/A4?
cards.back:
20 inches.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: What is the overall length of the M4 (stock extended)?
cards.back:
33 inches.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: What is the weight of the M4 carbine (with empty magazine)?
cards.back:
6.49 pounds (2.94 kg).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: What does the acronym SPORTS stand for?
cards.back:
Slap, Pull, Observe, Release, Tap, Squeeze (immediate action for malfunction).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: What is the first step in SPORTS?
cards.back:
SLAP the magazine upward to ensure proper seating.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: What is the second step in SPORTS?
cards.back:
PULL the charging handle to the rear.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: What is the third step in SPORTS?
cards.back:
OBSERVE the ejection port to see if a round or case ejects.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: What is the fourth step in SPORTS?
cards.back:
RELEASE the charging handle (do not ride it forward).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: What is the fifth step in SPORTS?
cards.back:
TAP the forward assist to ensure bolt is fully seated.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: What is the sixth step in SPORTS?
cards.back:
SQUEEZE the trigger and continue engagement.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: What are the four fundamentals of marksmanship?
cards.back:
Steady Position, Aim, Breath Control, Trigger Squeeze.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-2)

cards.front: What is sight alignment?
cards.back:
The relationship between the front sight post and rear sight aperture. Front sight centered in rear aperture.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-8)

cards.front: What is sight picture?
cards.back:
The relationship between sight alignment and the target. Proper sight alignment placed on center mass.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-9)

cards.front: Where should the tip of the front sight post be aimed?
cards.back:
Center mass of the target.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-9)

cards.front: When should you apply trigger squeeze?
cards.back:
During the natural respiratory pause (after exhaling).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-11)

cards.front: What is the proper trigger finger placement?
cards.back:
Use the center of the first pad of the trigger finger (pad between tip and first joint).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-12)

cards.front: What is the natural respiratory pause?
cards.back:
The brief moment after exhaling, before inhaling, when the body is most relaxed.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-10)

cards.front: At what distance is the M4/M16 zeroed?
cards.back:
25 meters (300 meter zero using 25m target).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 6, para 6-2)

cards.front: What is the relationship between the 25-meter and 300-meter zero?
cards.back:
At 25m, the bullet is still rising. It crosses the line of sight again at 300m (ballistic trajectory).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 6, para 6-2)

cards.front: How many rounds are required to confirm zero?
cards.back:
Two consecutive 3-round groups within a 4cm circle.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 6, para 6-8)

cards.front: What direction do you move the front sight post to raise point of impact?
cards.back:
DOWN. Front sight moves opposite the desired impact change.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 6, para 6-5)

cards.front: What direction do you move the rear sight to move impact right?
cards.back:
RIGHT. Rear sight moves in the same direction as desired impact change.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 6, para 6-6)

cards.front: How much does one click of the front sight post move point of impact at 25m?
cards.back:
Approximately 1.5 centimeters.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 6, para 6-5)

cards.front: What is a Failure to Feed malfunction?
cards.back:
A round fails to strip from the magazine and enter the chamber. Usually caused by magazine issues.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-7)

cards.front: What is a Failure to Fire malfunction?
cards.back:
Trigger pulled but no round fires. Usually caused by faulty primer or firing pin issues.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: What is a Failure to Extract malfunction?
cards.back:
The spent case fails to be removed from the chamber. Usually caused by dirty chamber or broken extractor.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-9)

cards.front: What is a Failure to Eject malfunction?
cards.back:
Spent case extracts but does not leave the receiver (stovepipe). Usually weak ejector spring or short stroke.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-10)

cards.front: What is a double feed?
cards.back:
Two rounds attempting to enter the chamber simultaneously. Requires remedial action (not SPORTS).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-11)

cards.front: How do you clear a double feed?
cards.back:
Lock bolt to rear, remove magazine, cycle bolt 3 times, insert new magazine, chamber round.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-12)

cards.front: What are the three firing positions (basic)?
cards.back:
Prone (supported/unsupported), Kneeling, and Standing.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 4, para 4-2)

cards.front: Which firing position is most stable?
cards.back:
Prone supported (lowest profile, most contact with ground).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 4, para 4-3)

cards.front: Which firing position is least stable?
cards.back:
Standing (highest center of gravity, least support).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 4, para 4-6)

cards.front: What is the advantage of the kneeling position?
cards.back:
Good balance of stability and mobility. Can be assumed quickly.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 4, para 4-5)

cards.front: What is the standard qualification distance for the M4/M16?
cards.back:
50 to 300 meters (pop-up targets at various distances).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 8, para 8-2)

cards.front: What are the three qualification ratings?
cards.back:
Expert (36-40 hits), Sharpshooter (30-35 hits), Marksman (23-29 hits).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 8, para 8-5)

cards.front: How many rounds are fired during rifle qualification?
cards.back:
40 rounds (20 prone supported, 10 prone unsupported, 10 kneeling).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 8, para 8-3)

cards.front: What is the minimum qualifying score?
cards.back:
23 hits out of 40 (Marksman).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 8, para 8-5)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the forward assist?
cards.back:
To fully seat the bolt carrier group when it fails to lock.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the charging handle?
cards.back:
To manually cycle the bolt carrier group (chamber a round, clear malfunctions).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-9)

cards.front: What type of gas system does the M4/M16 use?
cards.back:
Direct impingement (gas is channeled through a tube to cycle the bolt).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-3)

cards.front: What is the rifling twist rate of the M4 barrel?
cards.back:
1:7 (one complete rotation every 7 inches).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, Table 1-1)

cards.front: What are the selector switch positions on the M4?
cards.back:
SAFE, SEMI (single shot), and BURST (3-round burst) or AUTO.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-5)

cards.front: What must be done before placing the selector on SAFE?
cards.back:
The hammer must be cocked (bolt must be to the rear or weapon fired).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-5)

cards.front: What are the eight major groups of the M4/M16?
cards.back:
Upper receiver, lower receiver, bolt carrier group, charging handle, barrel, handguards, buttstock, small parts.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-2)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the ejection port cover?
cards.back:
To prevent dirt and debris from entering the receiver when closed.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-7)

cards.front: What are the two types of rear sight apertures on the M16A2?
cards.back:
Large (0-2) for close/low light and small (unmarked) for precision shooting.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-11)

cards.front: What is the function of the buffer assembly?
cards.back:
Absorbs recoil energy and returns the bolt carrier group forward.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-15)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the compensator on the M4?
cards.back:
Reduces muzzle rise during firing by redirecting gases.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-16)

cards.front: What is CLP used for?
cards.back:
Cleaner, Lubricant, and Preservative - all-purpose weapons maintenance.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-2)

cards.front: What is the first step in clearing the M4/M16?
cards.back:
Point the muzzle in a safe direction.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What is the second step in clearing the M4/M16?
cards.back:
Remove the magazine.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What is the third step in clearing the M4/M16?
cards.back:
Lock the bolt to the rear.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What is the fourth step in clearing the M4/M16?
cards.back:
Visually inspect the chamber and receiver for ammunition.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What is the M855 round commonly called?
cards.back:
Green tip or penetrator round (steel core for armor penetration).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, para 1-5)

cards.front: What is the M193 round?
cards.back:
Standard 5.56mm ball ammunition (55 grain, full metal jacket).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, para 1-4)

cards.front: What is the M856 round used for?
cards.back:
Tracer round (orange/red tip) for signaling and observing fire.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, para 1-6)

cards.front: What is the M862 round?
cards.back:
Short Range Training Ammunition (SRTA) - plastic bullet for close range training.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, para 1-7)

cards.front: What color tip identifies M855 ammunition?
cards.back:
Green tip.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, para 1-5)

cards.front: What color tip identifies tracer ammunition?
cards.back:
Orange or red tip.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 1, para 1-6)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the gas tube?
cards.back:
Channels propellant gases from the barrel to the bolt carrier to cycle the action.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-3)

cards.front: What is the bolt face?
cards.back:
The portion of the bolt that contacts the base of the cartridge.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-12)

cards.front: What is the function of the extractor?
cards.back:
Grips the cartridge rim to pull the case from the chamber.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-13)

cards.front: What is the function of the ejector?
cards.back:
Spring-loaded plunger that pushes the spent case out of the ejection port.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-14)

cards.front: What is a 'cook-off'?
cards.back:
Unintended discharge caused by chambered round igniting from barrel heat.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-15)

cards.front: How do you prevent a cook-off?
cards.back:
Avoid sustained fire exceeding rate limits; open bolt after sustained fire to cool.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-15)

cards.front: What is a 'hangfire'?
cards.back:
Delay between trigger pull and round firing. Keep muzzle pointed downrange for 15 seconds.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-14)

cards.front: What is a 'squib load'?
cards.back:
Round with insufficient propellant that lodges bullet in bore. DO NOT fire again.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-16)

cards.front: What is the primary cause of weapon stoppages?
cards.back:
Poor maintenance and lack of lubrication.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-3)

cards.front: What areas require lubrication on the M4/M16?
cards.back:
Bolt carrier group rails, charging handle, buffer spring, trigger mechanism.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 3, para 3-4)

cards.front: What is 'bone support' in marksmanship?
cards.back:
Using skeletal structure rather than muscles to support the weapon, reducing fatigue and tremor.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-4)

cards.front: What is 'muscular relaxation' in marksmanship?
cards.back:
Keeping muscles relaxed to prevent trembling; use only enough tension to hold position.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-5)

cards.front: What is 'natural point of aim'?
cards.back:
Where the weapon naturally points when the firer is relaxed. Adjust body position, not muscle tension.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-6)

cards.front: What is 'trigger reset'?
cards.back:
Releasing trigger only until it clicks forward, then squeezing again without full release.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-13)

cards.front: What is a 'controlled pair'?
cards.back:
Two rapid shots fired using trigger reset between each round.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 7, para 7-4)

cards.front: What is 'follow-through' in marksmanship?
cards.back:
Maintaining position and sight picture after the shot breaks to observe impact.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-14)

cards.front: What is 'calling the shot'?
cards.back:
Announcing where the bullet impacted based on sight picture at moment of firing.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-15)

cards.front: What causes 'anticipation' in marksmanship?
cards.back:
Flinching or pushing the weapon in expectation of recoil. Results in low shots.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-18)

cards.front: What causes 'jerking the trigger'?
cards.back:
Snatching the trigger instead of squeezing. Results in shots low and left (right-handed).

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-17)

cards.front: What is the dominant eye?
cards.back:
The eye used primarily for aiming. Usually same side as dominant hand.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-7)

cards.front: How do you determine dominant eye?
cards.back:
Extend arms, make triangle with thumbs/fingers, center distant object, close each eye - dominant eye keeps object centered.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 5, para 5-7)

cards.front: What is the 'supported firing position' in prone?
cards.back:
Using sandbags or improvised rest under the handguard for maximum stability.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 4, para 4-3)

cards.front: What is the 'sitting position'?
cards.back:
Alternative position using crossed legs for support. More stable than kneeling, faster than prone.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 4, para 4-7)

cards.front: What is the 'squatting position'?
cards.back:
Low position with feet flat on ground. Used for quick shots from behind low cover.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 4, para 4-8)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the AN/PEQ-15?
cards.back:
Infrared laser aiming device and illuminator for night operations with NVGs.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 9, para 9-2)

cards.front: What is the CCO (M68)?
cards.back:
Close Combat Optic - battery-powered red dot sight with unlimited eye relief.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-25)

cards.front: What is the ACOG?
cards.back:
Advanced Combat Optical Gunsight - 4x magnification scope with bullet drop compensator.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 2, para 2-26)

cards.front: What is 'battlesight zero' (BZO)?
cards.back:
A 300-meter zero that allows engagement of targets from 0-300m with center mass hold.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 6, para 6-10)

cards.front: What is 'range estimation'?
cards.back:
Determining distance to target using known sizes, unit measure, or appearance methods.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 7, para 7-2)

cards.front: What is the '100-meter unit of measure' method?
cards.back:
Mentally visualize 100m segments between you and target. Count segments for range estimate.

(Source: TC 3-22.9, Ch 7, para 7-3)
